displayed_text: Patient: For the nerves. Doctor: Napercin is a – for – like Ibuprofen uh like you had something for your bathroom Patient: That - That was a long time ago. Patient: Yes. Yep. Doctor: And atorvastatin forty milligrams times a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: A pro-antibiotic once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Calcium or Vitamin B once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Cranberry extract once a day? Patient: Yep.

Patient: No. Doctor: What do I have to get together again? What? Hey, you guys are wearing the same shirt. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Is that on purpose for filming? Family Member: No. Oh, I don’t know. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. I was just checking. My other couple also dressed up but she was in blue and he was in pink. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: It looked like they should be in a catalog. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So, I wasn’t sure if it was like Tigers day or. Family Member: I know. Yes. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Just working zone. (Laughter)

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we did tissue testing because one of the ways of resistance is if they had that P10 loss which your tissue did. And that’s why we put you on this uh medication that at least you’ve tolerated amazingly well. I mean you really haven’t had any side effects, haven’t felt any different, managed to keep up with everything you want to do. So that’s been remarkable. The PSA last couple of times as we discussed last time has been going up. Okay. One of my concerns is if it keeps going up but the scans don’t change, do we stay the same course? And honestly for how well you’re doing, that’s what I’m tempted to do. Okay. If however your bone scan shows me new areas or things growing then we are going to stop this treatment and go to something else. Patient: I see. Doctor: Now as we sort of discussed a little bit, the something else could either be going back and doing chemotherapy with Dr. K____ okay that’s a potential option. And, or if we want to give it one more try with doing a different kind of hormonal therapy, we have a new hormone therapy agent that we are testing here you know that’s been through multiple people who have had it and there’s been some promising results initially so I think that would be another option. Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But you know so those are probably the potential choices. The third possible choice and that would depend on your CAT scans had some lymph nodes though that were seen so there is a study with a combination of two different therapies. Okay? One is the Xofigo which is a radiation treatment that’s approved. You’ve probably heard of it I know. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: It’s a treatment that only goes to the bones in prostate cancer and helps kill the cancer in the bones. Most of your disease was in the bones. Okay but you also had lymph nodes in the belly that were related to the prostate cancer. Patient: Oh. Family Member: No I didn’t know that. Okay. Doctor: So at least on the up front CAT scan, not the latest one. Family Member: Oh, oh, oh

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - you have a two out of three chance of getting the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately to that lymph node. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or you can have a one out of three chance to get in the observation group first. If you go in the observation group you’re gonna get no additional therapy. You’ll be getting your PSA checked every other month. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If there’s another increase by fifty percent of then Patient: Okay. What’s the timeframe for the observation? Are we talking like a six month period of observations or what you’re saying that if I for whatever was to receive the observation does that one day receive the observation that would just remain until I hit the forty-two which could be like it could be a year? Doctor: So that’s, so that’s where the Patient: Okay. Doctor: You raise a very good question. Then if you go with the observation group and the PSA would still rise

Patient: That’s different than this. Doctor: Yeah, because this this genotype that we're looking for- it does not predispose you to cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: This is something that's very common in the population. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We just think that these people are more likely to respond to antioxidants. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: But the, yeah, so the, I can print this out for you too, just so that you have it for your records. The testing to see if you have the hereditary risk of cancer was negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright, so of these options, what I think is reasonable, and what I think is not reasonable. Observation for you actually, I don't think is reasonable. You're a pretty healthy guy. You're a pretty healthy guy. And you don't have any comorbidities. You know, I would expect you to live if you didn't have prostate cancer, I would expect to live for at least another 10 years. So I think that we should do something more than observation, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So this one would not be my first choice. Intermittent hormone therapy, I think if you wanted to go for a standard approach, like what everybody else is doing, I think that that is a very reasonable option. The downside is that you would be exposed to hormone therapy. And when we get to, if you ever get to this phase where you have metastatic disease where we can see your lymph nodes or see disease in the bones, you get started on hormonal hormone therapy anyways. So what usually happens in this approach is that you're getting it every six months. And, you know, maybe you get it for six months and you’re off of it for two years, maybe three years together for six months or a year, go for six months necessarily. This is certainly not a bad option. This is the standard option. This is what we consider the standard of care, like what's most widely accepted. And this could be an option now or later. You know, having talked to you before. I think what we should maybe try and do first is see if you'd be eligible and if you have this genotype for the MAP study.

Patient: So uh hum, okay, okay. Doctor: It’s not going to drop by like ninety-nine percent. So don’t expect; with hormone therapy, that’s what usually happens - Patient: Yeah I got it. Doctor: - You get a dramatic drop. When you get a drop because cancer is dying. With this, if this was truly the only lymph node. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know then you would expect the PSA to drop by like ninety percent. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know if this is one of five lymph nodes, and you know the other four are invisible, then you drop by twenty percent. Family Member: If it drops by twenty percent, then we’ll know okay somewhere else - Doctor: cancer; we’ll look at the majority of the cancer where eighty percent went somewhere else. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: In the meantime you’ve bought a few months, maybe a year, of not starting hormone therapy.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Questions. Patient: Well, the first question is of course- Doctor: Yep. Patient: -is side effects. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I haven't gotten, gotten down to that. Doctor: Oh, are you reading the consent? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah, so you know what I mean. Doctor: Mmm. Didn’t they give you a bigger version before you go blind looking at your phone, because it's like 30 pages of that stuff- Patient: Yeah, yeah.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So there there isn’t a but you’re not getting any therapy or you’re getting only a pla-placebo potentially. So, in response to what you just said which is you you wanna get some drug back into your system- Patient: Yup. Doctor: That the clinical trial will give you the option of doing that um potentially with something experimental out and on- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But not necessarily. Um just a couple of words about the side effects and they’re all listed in this consent form which is fourteen pages long, so it’s quite detailed. But um the main side effects are listed in section four and I will read that with you so you can look at it. We have seen some fatigue with this medication.

Family Member: but sometimes he gets snacks he shouldn’t have. Doctor: Yep. Family Member: But there’s not Metformin so we don’t have anything to combat all these sweets. So we need Doctor: Was he not taking Metformin at all? Family Member: No he’s got – they told him – and they reminded him today because of the alteration in his kidney function, Doctor: Oh okay because of that. Family Member: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor Doctor: Mm Hmm. Family Member: before all this treatment even started. Doctor: Really? Family Member: She was like… Doctor: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork

Patient: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles) Family Member: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question – Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand. Doctor: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh. Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know?

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: What do you do? Family Member: I’m a physical therapist, but I manage the rehab department at C____. Doctor: What’s your phone number? For whoever is going to take a phone call. Family Member: You’re giving all the phone calls to me (Laughs) Doctor: Let me just write down who you are. Family Member: I’m L___. Doctor: His wife is L. Same last name? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And she works… Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In your hospital.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: And how soon would that start? Doctor: Uh that would be more—again, based on scans and scheduling. Patient: Okay and then who’s going to order the scans? Doctor: So that’s what I’ve got to talk to Dr. G__ about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you’ve already got the test scans, what’s the plan? Because we need to get pictures to sort of say yes, you’ve progressed. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean I could do that. You know I just want to make sure that if he’s you know ultimately if he’s going to get you chemotherapy and the closer you get to there and that can be given anywhere, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know we might just let that system do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If that’s where you’ve had them before for comparison sakes, then - Patient: I haven’t had chemo there.

Family Member: Right. Just quit getting – we can’t have spaghetti for Father’s Day. Doctor: No. You can have squash spaghetti. Family Member: Yeah. I could see my daughter-in-law making that. (Laughter) Doctor: I’m just saying, you can have spaghetti, just not pasta. Family Member: Pasta. Right. Not cereal. We need to get rid of the Special K. Doctor: No cereal. No bread. No pasta. Patient: So then I’m eating, uh- Family Member: My diet. Doctor: You’re just eating protein. Patient: Seven days a week eating eggs. Doctor: Well, there’s other foods other than eggs. But carbs for you are like, forget it. Forget it. They’re disastrous. Family Member: Cancer feeds on it.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You could get regular Taxotere, Taxotere forever if you wanted to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now your hands and feet won’t let you do it because you might get numb. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, you know, numb hands and feet, but in general the trial allows you to do that and then if you’re not on the vitamin C everybody starts to get the vitamin C. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You kind of pretty much know if you are on the vitamin C though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you do get flushing and you know kind of like what you think about high-dose vitamins. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so I think it’s worth a go at least to think about it.

Patient: Uh, I don’t know, I guess I’d be alright. I’m back walking. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I couldn’t walk then. It got bad. Doctor: Gosh. Patient: I went to the hospital. Doctor: Yeah. Gosh. Could you, uh, uh breathe without oxygen? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah? That was okay? Patient: They put a, they put a little thing in the nose. Doctor: Okay. But I see you don’t need it. So that’s a good sign. Did they give antibiotics while you were there? Patient: Not, not with me. Family Member: Not to take home.
